dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On September 28, activists around the world will mark International Safe Abortion Day, an opportunity to mourn those who have died because of oppressive anti-abortion laws. But this day is also about spreading a message on behalf of Elizabeth and other women like her: Abortion, while in many countries a political wedge issue, is simply a fact of life.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's just horrific. And the article points out this isn't new; abortion was, uh, normal in ancient civilizations. It was only in the 19th century that, like, Catholic and colonial elites pushed these anti-abortion laws.

dialogue_turns.text: To control women's sexuality, you know, bodies, lives. But, the thing is, criminalization doesn't reduce abortions. It just makes them more dangerous.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: To control women's sexuality, you know, bodies, lives. But, the thing is, criminalization doesn't reduce abortions. It just makes them more dangerous.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But, contrary to popular opinion, criminalization does not reduce the number of abortions; it only makes having one more dangerous.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Completely. Look at Romania and South Africa. After decriminalization, maternal deaths fell by half in Romania, and 91% in South Africa. The evidence is just so clear.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Completely. Look at Romania and South Africa. After decriminalization, maternal deaths fell by half in Romania, and ninety one percent in South Africa. The evidence is just so clear.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, a year after Romania decriminalized abortion in 1990, maternal deaths fell by half, while in South Africa, deaths plummeted 91% in the first four years after passage of the 1996 Choice on Termination of Pregnancy Act.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. There's just no medical reason for a woman to risk her life for this. And yet, the fight continues. Ireland was a big victory, but, um, the challenges are still huge.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Simply put, there is no medical reason why any woman should have to risk her life to end an unwanted pregnancy. ... In May, voters in Ireland repealed the countrys abortion ban, a significant victory in a society so deeply influenced by its Catholic faith.
